awd_titl_txt: CAREER: Molecular Evolution and Genetics of Hybrid Sterility in Mimulus
awd_abstract_narration:
The evolution of reproductive isolation is central to both the process of how new species arise and the origin of biodiversity on the planet. One important criterion for classifying two organisms as separate species is their inability to interbreed. However, little is known about the particular genes that prevent different species from forming viable offspring. The goal of this research is to identify the genes that cause hybrid sterility between two closely related species of the model plant Mimulus (monkeyflowers), a genus of wildflowers native to western North America. With innovative crossing designs and field experiments, this work will determine which genes maintain species, as well as characterize the molecular functions and evolutionary dynamics of these genes in nature. 

This project represents a significant contribution toward understanding the molecular, genetic, and evolutionary mechanisms that underlie the origin of species. This research will generate valuable plant collections and genome sequence data that will add to the general utility of the Mimulus model system. In addition, this proposal details a plan for engaging a broad audience in evolutionary genetics research, including local high school teachers who will develop hands-on Mimulus lab activities for use in their own classrooms. The proposal also includes a plan to reform undergraduate biology education by integrating research into the learning experiences of a diverse student population. In collaboration with a team of education specialists, the principal investigator will develop a Mimulus undergraduate research project for use in the University of Georgia's large enrollment introductory biology course series with the long-term goal of improving student learning and retention in the sciences.

por.por_cntn:
Science:

The origin and maintenance of biodiversity depends on the evolution of reproductive isolation between diverging populations. Since Darwin, evolutionary biologists have sought to explain the emergence of species barriers and coexistence of new species with related species. This research has focused on the evolution of postzygotic isolation — barriers that occur after mating between species as a result of F1 hybrid lethality and sterility. Unlike ecologically based barriers, which may be transient or disappear with changes in the environment, postzygotic barriers to hybridization are almost impossible to reverse once complete. By focusing on hybrid incompatibilities between species of the model flowering plant genus Mimulus, this research has made substantial progress toward characterizing the molecular functions of hybrid incompatibility genes and understanding their dynamics in natural populations.

A major outcome of this project was to genetically map two hybrid sterility loci between closely related Mimulus species (M. guttatus and M. nasutus) to small (< 70 kb) nuclear genomic regions that include strong candidate genes. Using classical genetic crosses and population genomics, we showed that a 320-kb region containing one of the incompatibility alleles has risen to intermediate frequency by strong natural selection within a single population of M. guttatus. In a series of crosses, we found no evidence of biased transmission of the sweeping incompatibility allele within M. guttatus, providing little support for selfish evolution as the cause of its recent increase in frequency. Finally, we used this hybrid sterility system to investigate the relationship between regulatory evolution within species and reproductive isolation between species. Although we found evidence for compensatory evolution in gene regulatory networks within Mimulus species, it did not explain rampant gene misexpression in hybrids.

Another outcome of this funding was a genetic analysis of hybrid seed inviability between two species of Mimulus, M. guttatus and M. tilingii. We discovered that F1 hybrid seed failure between these species is an exceptionally strong reproductive isolating barrier and is primarily caused by genetic loci with parent-of-origin effects, suggesting a possible role for imprinted genes and genomic coevolution within lineages.

This project also included research into the genetic basis and evolutionary dynamics of hybrid lethality between two inbred lines of M. guttatus and M. nasutus that co-occur in nature. We discovered that hybrid lethality arises in a fraction hybrid seedlings due to unlinked duplicate copies of a nuclear gene essential for chloroplast development. In this cross, the M. nasutus line carries only one (ancestral) copy of the gene, whereas the M. guttatus line carries a nonfunctional ancestral copy and a functional duplicate copy on a distinct chromosome. Hybrid seedlings lack chlorophyll (and die) when they inherit only M. nasutus alleles at the duplicated locus and defective M. guttatus alleles at the ancestral copy. In a follow-up crossing study investigating natural variation at these loci, we showed that hybrid lethality is likely to be an active form of reproductive isolation in areas with ongoing interspecific gene flow.

Together, these projects have provided major insight into the molecular mechanisms and population genetic forces that drive the evolution of reproductive isolation between species.

Education:

With this funding, we have integrated evolutionary genetics research into biology curricula, with particular emphasis on laboratory development for K-12 and introductory undergraduate courses. I have developed a Course-based Research Experience (CURE) using Mimulus that teaches fundamental skills in genetics, evolution, and bioinformatics. For the past seven years, I have honed and improved this CURE in my Evolutionary Genetics lab course at UGA and I am now working to prepare this activity for national dissemination. Additionally, during six summers of this grant, my lab hosted four local K-12 teachers (three of them from schools with large majorities of Black and Latinx students). In collaboration with these teachers, we have developed hands-on lab activities using Mimulus to teach concepts in genetics and evolution to middle and high school biology students. Finally, this funding has provided training and mentoring to individuals from diverse backgrounds including more than 20 undergraduate students, five graduate students, and two postdoctoral researchers.
